title: Vice Media Trims Staff at Viceland in Pivot Toward News
text:
Vice Media LLC is cutting staff at its cable channel Viceland, part of a broader reorganization intended to sharpen its focus on news programming, according to people familiar with the matter.

The job cuts, some of which took place Thursday, impact about 15 people across multiple departments such as programming, marketing and research, the people said.

The layoffs are part of a strategy to move Viceland toward news and away from entertainment and other lifestyle programming, the people said. Vice Media is merging Vice News and Viceland and recently has added staffers to its news division, one of the people said.

Brooklyn, N.Y.-based Vice Media, primarily known as a digital-media company with edgy content aimed at younger audiences, launched Viceland in 2016, hoping to diversify its revenue and burnish its brand.

Employees who were laid off were told the network now has less need for in-house staffers, one of the people said.

Vice Media declined to comment.

Vice Media Chief Executive Nancy Dubuc has prioritized getting the company to profitability. The Wall Street Journal reported in late 2018 the company was on track to lose more than $50 million that year on revenue of $600 million to $650 million. In January, the company laid off about 10% of its workforce, or about 250 jobs.

The company exceeded its revenue goals in the first half of 2019, according to a person familiar with the matter.

Ms. Dubuc has prioritized five core areas of investment for the company, including a studio business that produces movies and television shows for third parties, news, digital, TV and Virtue, its in-house advertising agency.

In May, Vice raised $250 million in debt from a group of investors that included George Soros.
